repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second Technical assistance
            Project for the Public and Private Provision of Infrastructure

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Technical Assistance Project
            for the Public and Private Provision of Infrastructure is
            rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as modest, Bank performance
            as satisfactory, and borrower performance as satisfactory.
            Many lessons learned from the project include: Private
            participation in infrastructure development should be
            integrated within the overall infrastructure framework.
            There was resistance to change from the old ways of
            infrastructure development due to fear that the private
            sector will win concessions through corrupt connections and
            exploit consumers by maximizing profits and providing poor
            service. Introducing effective competition and independent
            regulatory bodies working with consumers associations is
            necessary to allay these fear. A public-private partnership
            information center or network will facilitate information
            dissemination. It was clear from the project that
            sub-projects with an enthusiastic and influential supporter
            within the government were much more likely to proceed to
            the physical implementation of infrastructure development.
            These champions can help to overcome government and public
            resistance to private sector participation (PSP) policy.
            There is a need to strengthen and deepen financial markets.
            Continued support for development of the PSP framework is
            needed. Demonstration projects are essential.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second Technical Assistance
            Project for Public and Private Provision of Infrastructure

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Technical
            Assistance for Public and Private Provision of
            Infrastructure Project is to assist the Government of
            Indonesia to: 1) assess strategic priorities for reducing
            infrastructure bottlenecks; 2) develop an updated strategy
            for public-private partnerships and suitable frameworks for
            private participation in provision of infrastructure
            services; 3) redefine the relative roles of the central and
            local authorities in the identification, preparation and
            implementation of infrastructure projects; and 4) enhance
            program evaluation capability within BAPPENAS National
            Planning Development Agency and regional planning bodies and
            project preparation and implementation capabilities in line
            agencies and local governments responsible for various
            infrastructure investments. The project will support the
            preparation of national sector policies and planning
            studies; strategies to develop institutions and design
            regulation to strengthen public/private partnership in the
            provision of infrastructure services and feasibility
            studies, engineering designs, environmental and resettlement
            assessments and remedial plans. It will also include reviews
            by independent experts of studies as well as unsolicited
            proposals by private investors, and audits of selected major
            assignments to evaluate their impact of institutional
            development. Finally it will finance the training of staff.
